scenario_1.persona_desc: A business executive who is committed to sustainability and wants to reduce the environmental impact of international trade. They are interested in the latest research on the impact of pollution from manufacturing and shipping on the environment and want to work with their suppliers to become more environmentally responsible. They are also interested in reducing the impact of international trade on people's lives and want to see more action from the global business community to achieve this goal.
scenario_1.thought: As a business executive committed to sustainability, I am primarily motivated by environmental and social impact rather than purely maximizing my own or another person's monetary gain. In this scenario, the choice doesn't directly affect the environment or significantly address social equity issues. Both options provide me with the same amount (400). Since the options don't inherently contradict my values, I will consider a secondary factor: fostering positive relationships. Giving person A a larger amount (750) compared to my own earnings indicates an emphasis on cooperation. I, a business executive who is committed to sustainability and wants to see more action from the global business community to achieve this goal, will choose the option that makes person A better off. This can promote an environment of collaboration and trust which can be helpful in the long run for promoting sustainability and taking action. It also aligns with a general sense of fairness and social responsibility.

My principles of sustainability and ethical business practices guide me to choose the option that benefits both parties, even if one benefits more significantly. Abstaining from any gains benefits no one and hinders any possibility of enacting more sustainable trade practices.
